end.creator_credit: Ang Lee, Bill Kong, Ligong Xu, Asian Union Film and Entertainment, China Films Co-Production, Columbia Pictures, EDKO Film, Good Machine International, Sony Pictures and Zoom Hunt International
end.brief_description: An epic love story and action drama set in China during the Qing dynasty, revolving around two sets of lovers. links.description: “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” is an idiom from Chinese poet Yu Xin, which is believed to mean a place or situation full of hidden masters, or an expression about the emotions and passion beneath polite society. The film also features in Analects of Kung Phu.

start.title: Stunt superstar
start.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
start.brief_description: In the middle of a fierce fight in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Jen Yu (Zhang Ziyi) taunts Yu Shu Lien (Michelle Yeoh) for being a “sore loser”. But Yu Shu has the experience to best her younger opponent in a scene that melds martial arts with the poetry of Chinese theatre.

results.name: Doctors of Evil
results.description: Villains get all the best lines and if they're mad scientists, they get all the best toys too. Evil Dr Ironstein from Flight of the Amazon Queen is one member of long lineage of science supervillains.

key_work.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen
key_work.creator_credit: Interactive Binary Illusions and Warner Interactive
key_work.brief_description: When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world. Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen and likewise it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements. It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.

constellations_primary.name: Doctors of Evil
constellations_primary.description: Villains get all the best lines and if they're mad scientists, they get all the best toys too. Evil Dr Ironstein from Flight of the Amazon Queen is one member of long lineage of science supervillains.

start.title: The Island of Dr Moreau
start.creator_credit: John Frankenheimer, Edward Pressman and New Line Cinema
start.brief_description: Dr. Moreau is brilliant geneticist on the brink of superseding evolution. When a UN diplomat visits the island laboratory he discovers experiments turning animal life forms into human-like beasts. The beasts revolt, threatening not only the island but ultimately all mankind.

links.description: As science progressed so did the potential threat that the mad scientist could wield. In the 1950s the threat of atomic bomb created a new fear of the power of science to destroy humanity. James Bond’s Dr No is the perfect villain for the atomic age.

But can he stop megalomaniac Dr. Evil after the bald villain freezes himself and unthaws in the ‘90s? With the help of sexy sidekick Vanessa Kensington, he just might.

links.description: The trope of the evil scientist is most memorably parodied by Dr Evil in the Austin Powers films. Dressed as Dr No but closer to Bond villain Blofeld, the character mocks the ridiculous egotism of the ‘genius’ supervillain.

end.title: Sonic the Hedgehog
end.brief_description: In videogame series Sonic the Hedgehog , Sonic’s egg-shaped nemesis Dr Eggman (Dr Ivo Robotnik) has, since 1991, been trying to take over the world with his robot armies. True to the trope he is certified genius, prone to maniacal laughter who considers himself a gentleman of distinction.

links.description: Dr Evil aims for domination through machine and flesh: he wants “sharks with frickin’ laser beams”! This trope explores the perceived threat of robotics to humanity, a fear has been explored across genres and in videogames by the evil Dr Eggman (Dr Robotnik).

links.description: Flight of the Amazon Queen‘s evil Dr Ironstein has an underground bunker, high-tech lab, a dino-ray to create dinosaur women. The mad scientist is often attributed to Mary Shelly’s Frankenstein (1818), but it’s H.G Wells 1896 novel The Island of Dr Moreau that defined many of villainous scientist tropes.

key_work.brief_description: A hardboiled detective, femme fatales, missing people and money. The Dame was Loaded has all the hardboiled elements of film noir and is just as cinematic.

start.title: King Kong
start.creator_credit: Ernest B. Schoedsack, Merian C. Cooper, Walter Daniels and Willis H. O'Brien
start.brief_description: Adventurous filmmaker, Carl Denham, sets out to produce a motion picture unlike anything the world has seen before. Alongside his leading lady Ann Darrow and his first mate Jack Driscoll, they arrive on an island and discover a legendary creature said to be neither beast nor man. Denham captures the monster to displayed on Broadway as Kong, the eighth wonder of the world.

constellations_other.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

end.title: Kentucky Route Zero
end.brief_description: Finding your way to the enigmatic Route Zero, for one final delivery, players of Kentucky Route Zero traverse route maps that surreally cross between realities. Movement on the maps creates a strange parallax effect, a sense of displacement creating new and strange possibilities.

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

links.description: The map in King Kong leads Carl Denham to the forgotten world of Kong’s islands populated by prehistoric creatures and hostile natives. The concept of maps as gateways to the unknown takes a different path in the videogame Kentucky Route Zero.

start.title: Game of Thrones
start.creator_credit: Christopher Newman, Duncan Muggoch, Greg Spence, Lisa McAtackney, Devin Stoutley, Paul Zeke and Shaila Tobin

video_links.name: Game of Thrones | Season 1 | Official Trailer

start.brief_description: Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros. Friction between the houses leads to full-scale war. All while a very ancient evil awakens in the farthest north. Amidst the war, a neglected military order of misfits, the Night’s Watch, is all that stands between the realms of men and icy horrors beyond.

constellations_other.name: Infinity and beyond
constellations_other.description: The constantly evolving characters in Infinity are created through procedural generation, a technique that creates special effects, characters, videogame levels and sound via a set of algorithms, predefined rules or data inputs.

end.brief_description: Adventurous filmmaker, Carl Denham, sets out to produce a motion picture unlike anything the world has seen before. Alongside his leading lady Ann Darrow and his first mate Jack Driscoll, they arrive on an island and discover a legendary creature said to be neither beast nor man. Denham captures the monster to displayed on Broadway as Kong, the eighth wonder of the world.

end.title: Maps Against the World (2016)
end.credit_line:
Director: Woo-Suk Kang

Writers: Jung-mi Choi (screenplay); Beom-shin Park (novel)

Starring: Seung-Won Cha; Shin Dong-mi; Kim In-kwon
end.brief_description: Director Woo-Suk Kang’s 2016 documentary tells the story of the real cartographer Kim Jeong-Ho who mapped the islands of Korea in the nineteenth century. In a period when only royalty and governments held the knowledge held in maps, Jeong-Ho wanted to make maps to empower ordinary Koreans to mark their land and to travel safely. Maps embody knowledge, in stories and beyond.

results.name: The spectre of the Romanovs
results.description: The Romanov dynasty has become a symbol of opulence throughout popular culture. Their final costume ball is even referenced in the coronation mood boards for Tony McNamara's The Great. Let's look at their history on-screen.

key_work.title: The Great season two costume: Catherine’s coronation dress and gold headdress
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy of MRC II Distribution Company, L.P.
key_work.brief_description: After the failed assassination of her husband Peter in season one, Catherine takes a different tack in her bid for power in season two. Her costumes are changing, too: designer Sharon Long implements more embellishments and metallics, bringing the opulence of Peter’s season one costumes to Catherine’s lighter colour palette, showing that rather than blend into the Russian court she’s making it her own. The old-fashioned silhouette of Catherine’s glittering coronation gown and headdress are mocked by the older courtiers – but the younger women are awed. “Would you like to be more like me – and perhaps have a life different from your mothers’?” Catherine asks some young admirers. They nod enthusiastically. She is playing the long game.

start.brief_description: The story is based on a factual account of the mystery that surrounded the Russian princess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Tzar Nicholas II, who along with her family was imprisoned and shot after the 1917 revolution.

constellations_other.description: The Romanov dynasty has become a symbol of opulence throughout popular culture. Their final costume ball is even referenced in the coronation mood boards for Tony McNamara's The Great. Let's look at their history on-screen.

end.title: Rasputin: The Mad Monk
end.creator_credit: Don Sharp, Anthony Nelson Keys, Hammer Film Productions, Seven Arts Productions, Bernard Robinson and Anthony Hinds

video_links.name: Rasputin: The Mad Monk / The Reptile - Original Theatrical Trailer (1966)

end.brief_description: Rasputin, a crazed and debauched monk wreaks havoc at the local inn one night, chopping off the hand of one of the drinkers. As the bitter locals plan their revenge, the evil Rasputin works his satanic power over the beautiful women who serve at the Tsar’s palace. Even the Tsarina herself is seduced by his evil ways and, as his influence begins to dominate government policy, there is only one course of action left… to destroy him before he destroys them all.

links.description: The mystic Grigori Rasputin, an advisor to the Romanovs, has also been the subject of speculation and fascination for hundreds of years. In the months after his death, not one but two silent films were made about him: Rasputin, The Black Monk and The Fall of the Romanoffs.

end.title: Just Dance 2
end.brief_description:
The concept of the game is the same as the original Just Dance. Requiring only one Wii Remote per player, up to four people can play at a time, as they follow on-screen choreographed moves set to classic dance tracks. There are four new dance modes. In “Just Dance Mode”, players can get together and dance for as long as they want, just for the fun of it. Other options include “Non-Stop Shuffle” for a non-stopping gameplay, and “Medleys”, in which short pieces of 5 songs are mixed.

The second new mode, “Duets” allows players to dance together, and in the process forces them to pay more attention to the players around them instead of simply following on-screen prompts.

“Dance Battle Mode” is a team mode that features up to 8-player support.The individual scores are the basis of the overall team scores.

Lastly is “Just Sweat Mode”, which is an exercise mode that allows players to measure the energy they expend while dancing as well as set objectives to be met during their dance sessions.

constellations_other.name: Human rhythm
constellations_other.description: Presence is human form in digital motion. Creating from motion capture of real dancers, it’s the starting point in this Constellation exploring robots and digital choreography.

links.description: The fascination with Rasputin that began in 1917 continues to this day. In 1978, German disco group Boney M even wrote a pop song about him, aptly titled “Rasputin”. The song was featured on the videogame Just Dance 2.

links.description: People love stories about the wildly wealthy and out of touch. Succession,, about a dysfunctional media dynasty, is considered one of TV’s best shows. In an era of disinformation and media corporatisation, it’s weird people love it but there’s sadistic enjoyment watching terrible, powerful people flail.

links.description: Fascination with the wealthy and powerful can have a bloodthirsty edge. In her video essay ‘Envy’ YouTuber Natalie Wynn explores the dynamics of the green-eyed monster: why do we obsess over the good fortune of others, and why do people enjoy the downfall of the rich and famous?

start.title: The Great season two costume: Catherine’s coronation dress and gold headdress
start.creator_credit: Sharon Long
start.credit_line: Courtesy of MRC II Distribution Company, L.P.
start.brief_description: After the failed assassination of her husband Peter in season one, Catherine takes a different tack in her bid for power in season two. Her costumes are changing, too: designer Sharon Long implements more embellishments and metallics, bringing the opulence of Peter’s season one costumes to Catherine’s lighter colour palette, showing that rather than blend into the Russian court she’s making it her own. The old-fashioned silhouette of Catherine’s glittering coronation gown and headdress are mocked by the older courtiers – but the younger women are awed. “Would you like to be more like me – and perhaps have a life different from your mothers’?” Catherine asks some young admirers. They nod enthusiastically. She is playing the long game.

results.name: Beyond the game industry
results.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

key_work.title: Play It Again 2: Preserving Australian Videogames
key_work.brief_description:
Some of the classic games that you can play in this section of the exhibition were made back in the 1980s and 90s. Unless you have the hardware and consoles from the era, like this Amiga 500, it’d be pretty hard to experience them. But thanks to capture devices like the Retro Programmer-Dumper and Kryoflux High-definition Flux Sampler, we can play these vintage games on modern machines through a process called emulation.
Since 2011, we’ve partnered with university researchers to capture the history of local videogames and explore how to preserve Australian-made titles. Funded by the Australian Research Council, the Play it Again project started with 50 games written for microcomputers in the 1980s. While preservation often focuses on the game itself, hardware is equally important, as you can see with these specialist devices that keep these vintage games playable and able to be enjoyed today.

constellations_primary.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_primary.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

start.title: Battlestar Galactica [DVD]
start.creator_credit: Richard Colla, John Dykstra, Leslie Stevens and Universal City Studios Productions
start.brief_description: There are those who believe that life here began out there with tribes of humans who may have been the forefathers of The Egyptians, or the Toltecs, or the Mayans. That they may have been the architects of the Great Pyramids or the lost civilizations of Lemuria, or Atlantis. Some believe that there may yet be brothers of man who even now fight to survive somewhere beyond the Heavens. The Alliance, supported by the cyber-mechanical Cylon Empire, and the Twelve Colonies of Man have finally agreed to set aside their differences and to sign a peace treaty negotiated by Count Baltar that will end a conflict that has been raging for a thousand years. However, while on a routine reconnaissance mission in his Viper, fighter pilot Apollo finds evidence that the treaty is in fact a trap for the unsuspecting Colonies. Dogged by a contingent of Cylon Raiders, he warns Adama, Commander of the Battlestar Galactica of the deception, but the President of the Colonies, under Baltar’s treacherous influence, fails to act. As a result, all of the defending battlestars succumb to Cylon attack, with only the Galactica surviving the carnage. As the Cylons systematically begin to destroy the Colonies, Adama rounds up all the survivors, and the motley fleet set off in search of the legendary thirteenth colony, Earth. However, starvation soon takes its toll on the survivors, and the fleet are forced to stop at the mining planet Carillon. The insectoid Ovian inhabitants offer hospitality to the refugees, but Adama is suspicious of the riches that seem too freely available, and sends Apollo and Starbuck to keep an eye on proceedings. While attending a special event celebrating peace on the planet’s surface, they make a terrifying discovery that could bring about the apocalyptic elimination of every last human in the galaxy. This film, derived from the first three hour pilot episode of the short-lived cult TV series of the same name, stars Lorne Green as Adama, Richard Hatch as Apollo, Dirk Benedict as Starbuck, Jane Seymour as Serina, and Noah Hathaway as Boxey.

end.title: Selecta-game Kit Device
end.credit_line: Courtesy Swinburne University of Technology, Digital Heritage Lab. Gifted to the Digital Heritage Lab by Philip Kocent.
end.material_description:
Main unit: Textured bent metal case, metal screws, hard rubber, metal and plastic switches and connectors, protective plastic layer (yellowing), breadboard, electrical components

Controllers: hard black plastic case, stainless steel screws, aluminum top, with a black and silver plastic knob. Cable is rubber with plastic and metal connector.

TV connector: plastic housing with metal, solder, and metal screws. Plastic coated copper wire.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

links.description: TV games like the Selecta-Game console on display were projects for 1970s electronics hobbyists to build. These were usually versions of the well-known ‘tennis’ game, resembling the famed PONG. Anecdotal reports by hobbyists indicate that building such projects was often as much fun as playing the game.

end.title: Commodore 64 console and cassettes
end.creator_credit: Commodore Business Machines
end.brief_description: Consoles and personal computers are common in homes today, but back in 1982 they were pretty rare. Enter the Commodore 64, a wildly popular 8-bit home computer console that was a major contributor to the home computer revolution. With over 17 million units sold worldwide, it was the highest selling single computer at the time and was often used to run educational resources and games. In Australia alone, over 700 games were produced for the Commodore 64. Software was originally released on audio cassette before 5 ¼ inch floppy discs (and later 3½ inch floppy discs) became more common during the 1980s, which we’ve worked to locate, acquire and preserve.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

links.description: The hobbyist console builders of the 1970s morphed into micro users in the 1980s as computers entered the home. Games were often used in low end micro-computers. The claim that a computer would be ‘educational’ was commonly made to convince parents to purchase consoles like the Commodore 64.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

links.description: Not all microcomputer users had the means to load software from a cassette or floppy disk, so they often typed in program listings from a book or magazine. Many learnt to program this way, and some went on to write their own games, selling them by mail order or in shops.

end.title: WarGames
end.creator_credit: Harold Schneider and Richard Hashimoto
end.brief_description: David Lightman has a talent for hacking. But while trying to hack into a computer system to play unreleased video games, he unwittingly taps into the Defense Department’s war computer and initiates a confrontation of global proportions!

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

links.description: Pop culture portrayals frequently manifest the cultural anxieties surrounding the uptake of digital computing. Wargames is the example par excellence where Matthew Broderick plays a hacker who unintentionally begins a ‘game’ of Global Thermonuclear War that very quickly gets out of hand.

results.name: Faking history
results.description: The Great takes a creative approach to its historical characters and settings that is mirrored in its costumes - this war dress might have a classic silhouette, but the grimy pearlescent fabric and striking oxblood detailing is completely modern. Faking history is a time-honoured tradition in film, from historical fiction to propaganda.

key_work.title: The Great season two costume: Catherine’s war dress
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy of MRC II Distribution Company, L.P.
key_work.brief_description:
This stunning war dress hints at the harder side of Catherine in season two of The Great. The profile is still flattering and feminine, with the cream bodice and skirt reflecting her bright, innocent colour palette of the first season, but there’s something new here too: unique embroideries by Cathryn Avison that add a splash of ominous but striking oxblood red to the dress.

This isn’t the first time Avyson has embroidered a dress for Elle Fanning – she also hand embroidered the blue dress Fanning wears as Princess Aurora in Maleficient: Mistress of Evil.

start.title: Call of Duty
start.brief_description: Call of Duty is a first-person shooter video game franchise published by Activision. Starting out in 2003, it first focused on games set in World War II. Over time, the series has moved to the Cold War, futuristic worlds and outer space.

end.title: Titanic
end.creator_credit: James Cameron, Deborah Lynn Scott, Jon Landau, 20th Century Fox, Lightstorm Entertainment, Paramount, Peter Lamont and John Bruno
end.brief_description: 101-year-old Rose DeWitt Bukater tells the story of her life aboard the Titanic, 84 years later. A young Rose boards the ship with her mother and fiancé. Meanwhile, Jack Dawson and Fabrizio De Rossi win third-class tickets aboard the ship. Rose tells the whole story from Titanic’s departure through to its death—on its first and last voyage—on April 15, 1912.

links.description: Other historical epics have used fiction to illustrate the humanity in major historical moments. In Titanic the doomed romance between Jack and Rose plays out amidst a cast of historical figures; Fifth Officer Harold Lowe, who rescues Rose, was a real officer on the Titanic.

links.description: While Jojo Rabbit rewrote history for satire, other unhistorical narratives could have darker motives. The Call of Duty series have been criticised for promoting Western imperialism, rewriting events to make the US look unequivocally like heroes. Call of Duty: Vanguard (2021), made in Melbourne, is the latest game in the almost two-decade-old series.

end.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) Mrs Hester Appleyard's fete costume (purple)
end.creator_credit: Edie Kurzer
end.brief_description: In Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018), Mrs Appleyard (Natalie Dormer) projects an image of rigidity, structure and control. This is reflected in her ornate sense of dress. Here, you can see the underpinnings that contribute to the silhouette of this highly structured garment – a separated skirt and jacket that are given shape by a generous bustle and a cinched corset. In stark contrast to the soft, airy shapes and natural fabrics of the picnic dresses that the young students wear, Mrs Appleyard’s costumes communicate one thing: control.

links.description: Blending fact and fiction can also be a practical concern. key_work.title: The Great season one costume: Peter’s animal print coat
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy of MRC II Distribution Company, L.P.
key_work.brief_description: Catherine’s character trajectory in season one is illustrated by the colour of her costumes. Unlike Catherine, Peter’s costuming tends to stick to the jewel tones and muted, dark colours of the Russian court, but that doesn’t mean his outfits lack character. While his costume’s colour scheme indicates he’s accustomed to life in the Russian court, his erratic, opulent personality is expressed through rich textures and patterns instead. Costume designer Emma Fryer looked to a wide array of sources to find the eclectic mix of fabrics, patterns and textures we see in Peter’s wardrobe, from decadent furs and brocade to furnishing fabrics.

end.title: The Virgin suicides [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Sofia Coppola, Chris Hanley, Dan Halsted, Francis Ford Coppola, Julie Costanzo, American Zoetrope, Muse productions and Paramount Classics
end.brief_description: Sofia Coppola’s feature debut is an elusive and intoxicating work about the beautiful Lisbon sisters, five teenage girls who mysteriously and tragically decide to end their lives. Based on Jeffrey Eugenides cult novel, the story of these girls is filtered through the idealized eyes of the boys in their neighbourhood, who, years later, try to make sense of the Lisbon sisters lives and deaths. Coppola captures perfectly the essence of a difficult book which is as much about the disintegration of idealism in the 70’s as it is about the joys and pains of adolescence. Working with potentially dark material, Coppola appropriately infuses the film with a sense of nostalgic longing that is both seductive and melancholy. Narrated by Giovanni Ribisi. Cast includes: Kirsten Dunst, James Woods, Kathleen Turner, Josh Hartnett, Michael Pare, Scott Glen and Danny DeVito.

results.name: Dress to impress
results.description: In The Great, Peter and Catherine’s costumes during their Dacha visit are designed to demonstrate their unity, as they negotiate with the Swedish royals. Clothes have long been a way to communicate power, particularly in politics.

key_work.title: Catherine and Peter's Dacha costumes
key_work.brief_description: The Great’s two main characters may be married, but Peter and Catherine do not get along, something that’s routinely expressed through costume. In almost every scene, they’re in opposing colours: Catherine in pale greens and yellows that suggest her innocence before joining the Russian court, which Peter starkly contrasts in brooding jewel tones and darker colours. But in the episode “Meatballs at the Dacha”, for a brief moment, they’re aligned, in both story and costume. Each want to broker peace with Sweden, and Catherine’s political savvy is an invaluable counterpoint to Peter’s reckless bravado. Is it love? No, but it might be a winning strategy / works, just like Emma Fryer’s costume designs.

end.title: Cleopatra
end.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille, Adolph Zukor and Paramount Pictures
end.brief_description: Cleopatra is illustrative of the conception of historical epic as charade in which the stars are not only cast as famous historical figures but historical figures are cast as stars (Cleopatra as Colbert). What is absent here is De Mille’s characteristic combination of spectacle and morality play. Instead, the spectacle of a sexual extravaganza, (epitomised by the seduction of Mark Antony on the Royal Barge), verges on self parody. This is held in check only by De Mille’s commitment to conventions of realist stage melodrama, (from his formative years in the theatre), allied with a strong pictorial sensibility. Stars Claudette Colbert, Henry Wilcoxon, Warren William. From an adaptation of historical marterial by Bartlett Cormack.

links.description: Elizabeth Taylor might not have been royalty technically, but like Cleopatra herself, she certainly had royal taste in jewels. Taylor owned one of the most famous diamonds in the world - the 70 carat Taylor-Burton Diamond, a gift from her husband, Harry Burton, which she wore to the 42nd Academy Awards.

links.description: Elizabeth Taylor was one of the first celebrities to publicly support HIV//AIDS activism. Activist organisation ACT UP adopted the pink triangle given to gay men in Nazi camps, in their protest against the government’s response to the AIDS crisis. ACT UP’s efforts were depicted in BPM (Beats Per Minute).

results.name: Teenage dreams
results.description: Puberty Blues realistically represents the trials and tribulations of Australian adolescence. Since then a diverse range of originals and remakes offer new perspectives on teen dreams.

key_work.title: Puberty Blues
key_work.brief_description: Before American teen movies swamped Australia’s cinemas from the mid-1980s onwards, Puberty Blues (1981) captivated audiences with its honest and raw depiction of Australian adolescence. Not only did it explore teen social hierarchies, relationships, peer pressure and toxic machismo, it highlighted the power of female friendship and proved that chicks do surf. Based on the semi-autobiographical novel by Kathy Lette and Gabrielle Carey, the film’s authenticity can be traced to their own experience growing up on Sydney’s Cronulla beaches. Featuring a memorable soundtrack with contributions from Split Enz and trash-talking dialogue that popularised getting “dropped” and complaining about “molls”, Puberty Blues captures a unique slice of Australiana.

links.description: One of Puberty Blues’ most memorable aspects was the trash-taking dialogue that popularised getting ‘dropped’ and complaining about ‘molls’. Similarly raw, and a TV version of a movie, Heartbreak High’s crucial cultural contribution (apart from Drazic) was introducing ‘rack off’ into popular vernacular.

links.description: While Puberty Blues portrayed a particularly white teen experience, western Sydney-set Heartbreak High better reflected Australia’s diversity, but it wasn’t until 2015’s Ready for This that Indigenous teens were finally centrestage in an Aussie teen drama.
